summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorney Bobbi C. Sternheim to Judge Alison J. Nathan, opposing the Metropolitan Detention Center's (MDC) objection to allowing Maxwell weekend and holiday access to a laptop computer for discovery review. The letter argues that the MDC's prison computers are inadequate for handling millions of pages of discovery, and that restricting laptop access severely hampers Maxwell's ability to prepare her defense.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Sternheim
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell who wrote this letter to Judge Nathan arguing for Maxwell's continued weekend/holiday laptop access for discovery review.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Judge presiding over United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell case, recipient of this letter from defense counsel.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Accused in the case, currently detained at MDC, seeking access to laptop computer on weekends and holidays to review millions of pages of discovery for trial preparation.

persons.name: Sophia Papapetru
persons.context: Counsel for the Metropolitan Detention Center, copied on this letter regarding Maxwell's laptop access.

connections.description: Sternheim is Maxwell's defense attorney advocating for her client's access to discovery materials.
Maxwell is the defendant in a case being presided over by Judge Nathan.
Defense attorney communicating with the presiding judge regarding case management issues.

events.title: MDC Letter Objection to Laptop Access
events.description: The Metropolitan Detention Center sent a letter objecting to the court's order allowing Ghislaine Maxwell weekend and holiday access to a laptop computer for discovery review.

events.title: Defense Response to MDC Objection
events.description: Defense attorney Bobbi C. Sternheim writes to Judge Nathan opposing the MDC's objection and arguing for continued weekend/holiday laptop access for Maxwell.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
33 West 19th Street - 4th Floor, New York, New York 10011
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team is reviewing millions of pages of discovery documents produced by the government.
The MDC prison computers are incapable of reading significant portions of the discovery, including native files, Excel files, some video/audio files, and files requiring Cellebrite software.
Maxwell loses 10+ hours per week due to delays in receiving the laptop, problems with MDC computers, and inability to access computers during inmate counts.
Hard drives provided by the government have been mishandled by MDC staff, causing them to become degraded and unstable.
Maxwell is more restricted than other MDC inmates, having no human contact except with guards, some of whom have allegedly psychologically and physically abused her.
